concept.title: Identifying the information type
concept.shortdesc: Concept, task and reference topics contain different types of content. Concept topics contain explanations, task topics contain procedural steps, and reference topics contain tabular look-up information.

conbody.p: An important skill of an author working in a DITA environment is typing information correctly into information types.
Of the three base DITA information types:

ul.li: Concept topics are used for overviews of tasks or overviews of reference information. They tend to be short and simple.
Reference topics detail properties and other reference (as opposed to narrative) information, typically in tabular form.

conbody.p:
In some types of documents, an instruction may be described with a set of concept, task and reference topics. For example, the use of a car's alarm system may be covered by:
Alarm systems (concept)
Setting the alarm (task)
Alarm codes (reference)

Such a set of topics would be associated using a reltable, so that the topics would be linked or associated in the deliverable document. A typical procedure will require a concept topic and a task topic, and may require a reference topic.

While task information is generally easy to identify, it can be difficult to distinguish concept from reference information.

section.title: Rationale
section.p: Here's how Michael Gross of DCLNews describes topics following on from his camera manual example. In addition to breaking the documents into topics, DITA provides for three built-in topic types, Tasks (such as "Changing the Memory Card"), Concepts ("How Lighting Affects Your Pictures"), and References ("Physical Specifications of the Camera"). The types of topics would normally not have been defined in the source data. Just as in deciding where to break down your topics, you may need someone who knows the data to go through it and define DITA topic types.
